questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

  • Epigenetics refers to the study of heritable changes in gene expression or cellular phenotype that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Epigenetic mechanisms, such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation, can modify gene expression by adding or removing chemical marks on DNA or histone proteins, thereby influencing how genes are activated or silenced. These changes can be passed from one generation of cells to the next, making them heritable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence itself. They can result in alterations to the genetic code, potentially leading to changes in gene expression. Mutations are genetic changes and do not fall under the category of epigenetic modifications, which involve changes to gene expression without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation involves the rearrangement of genetic material between non-homologous chromosomes. It can lead to changes in gene positioning but is not primarily associated with epigenetic modifications like methylation and acetylation.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversion is a type of chromosomal rearrangement where a segment of a chromosome is reversed. Similar to translocation, it can result in changes in gene positioning but is not directly related to epigenetic modifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics has been defined and today is generally accepted as ‘‘the study of changes in gene function that are mitotically and/or meiotically heritable and that do not entail a change in DNA sequence.

 

Epigenetic modification of core histones (acetylation of specific lysine residues) facilitates an open structure and permits access to transcription factors for interaction with DNA. On the other hand, methylation at the CG sequence of the promoters transcriptionally inactivates chromatin.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Letulle technique

 

Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

Below image shows Letulle’s Method

 

 

Other Options:

 

Other Autopsy Techniques for Evisceration:

 

Option A. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

Below image shows Virchow’s Method

 

 

Option B. Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

Below image shows Rokitansky Method

 

 

Option C. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

Below image shows Ghon’s Method

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Letulle technique involves removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs en masse, preserving their relationships, and is preferred for infants to observe congenital abnormalities.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, PC dikshit, page 147

questions.text: A neonate was brought with complaints of poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, and cataract. Urine Benedict’s test was positive, while urine glucose was negative. The enzyme defective in this case is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The symptoms described—poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, cataract, and a positive Benedict’s test with negative urine glucose—are characteristic of classical galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This enzyme is crucial in the metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in tissues, leading to toxic effects including liver damage, cataract formation (oil drop cataract), and intellectual disability due to energy deficiency in the brain.

 

The positive Benedict’s test indicates the presence of a reducing sugar, which in this case is galactose, not glucose, explaining the negative glucose test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructokinase: This enzyme is involved in fructose metabolism, specifically converting fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Its deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, a benign and asymptomatic condition that does not cause the symptoms observed in this case.

 

Option B. Sucrase: Sucrase breaks down sucrose into glucose and fructose. Sucrase deficiency primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming sucrose (common in sugarcane juice). It is unrelated to the clinical presentation described.

 

Option D. Lactase: Lactase is responsible for the digestion of lactose into glucose and galactose. Its deficiency causes lactose intolerance, characterized by diarrhea, gas, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy, but does not lead to acidosis or cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites, resulting in serious clinical symptoms including cataracts and liver damage.

questions.text: What is the odor of a mummified body? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Odorless

 

A mummified body is characterized by the absence of moisture, leading to its preservation. This process results in the body becoming dry and leathery, which eliminates the conditions necessary for the growth of bacteria responsible for producing foul odors.

 

Mummification:

 

  • Odor: Mummified bodies are odorless due to the absence of moisture, which inhibits bacterial growth and decomposition.
  • Appearance: The body becomes dry and leathery, preserving it in a desiccated state.

 

Comparison with Other Types of Decomposition:

 

  • Adipocere Formation:
    • Odor: An adipocere body has a foul, rancid smell similar to decomposing fats.
    • Formation: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," forms when body fat undergoes a chemical transformation into a waxy substance, typically in moist environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pungent: This odor is might be present in cases of certain chemical exposures or other types of decomposition.

 

Option C. Putrid: This odor is characteristic of bodies undergoing typical decomposition, where bacterial activity produces foul-smelling gases.

 

Option D. Offensive: Similar to putrid, this term describes the unpleasant odors produced during the normal decomposition process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mummified body is odorless due to its dry and preserved state, an adipocere body which has foul rancid smell (like decomposing fats)

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

  • Deficiency of GALT is the primary cause of classic galactosemia, which results in the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the body and leads to the symptoms described.

 

Classical Galactosemia:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive in born error of metabolism due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

 

 

  • Due to the block in this enzyme, galactose-1- phosphate will accumulate in liver. This will inhibit galactokinase as well as glycogen phosphorylase. Hypoglycemia is the result.
  • Bilirubin uptake is less and bilirubin conjugation is reduced; so unconjugated bilirubin level is increased in blood.
  • There is enlargement of liver, jaundice and severe mental retardation.
  • Free galactose accumulates, leading to galactosemia. It is partly excreted in urine (galactosuria).
  • Galactose is reduced to dulcitol. The accumulation of dulcitol in the lens results in cataract due to its osmotic effect. This is called congenital cataract and is a very characteristic feature of galactosemia.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate may get deposited in renal tubules, producing tubular damage leading to generalized amino aciduria.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical manifestation including congenital cataract and presence of galactose in urine (positive benedicts test) as well as elevated blood galactose levels will help in the diagnosis.
    • Collection of fetal cells by amniocentesis may be useful in prenatal diagnosis. Heterozygous parents could be detected by elevated galactose level in blood after a galactose load.
  • Treatment: 
    • If lactose is withdrawn from the diet, most of the symptoms recede. But mental retardation, when established, will not improve. Hence early detection is most important. For affected infant lactose-free diet is given. Such special diets may be withdrawn after 4 years, when galactose-1-phosphate pyro phosphorylase becomes active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase is not directly related to galactose metabolism and is not the cause of galactosemia.

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type II Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose and galactitol in the blood and tissues. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Option D. UDP galactose-4-epimerase: UDP galactose-4-epimerase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type III Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose-1-phosphate and UDP-galactose. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to metabolize galactose properly, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through dietary adjustments are crucial for preventing long-term complications.

choices.text: See the snake brought by the relatives

questions.text: A farmer came after snake bite on right foot. There were 2 fang marks with pain, swelling, and bleeding at the site of snake bite and the patient's vitals are stable. What will be the first step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polyvalent ASV

 

Explanation:

 

Based on the presence of two fang marks, pain, swelling, and bleeding at the site of the snake bite on the farmer's right foot, it is most likely a viper snake bite, which is poisonous. The patient's vitals are stable, but the signs of envenomation are present. In all cases of envenomation, the main life-treating measure is administering antisnake venom (ASV). Polyvalent ASV 5000 units should be given as the first step in management whenever poisonous features, such as bleeding, are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Pressure immobilization: Immobilization is done for all snake bites, but, the Pressure immobilization is done for neurotoxic snakes but not for vasculotoxic snakes like vipers. Applying pressure in vasculotoxic snake bites can lead to local toxic effects and potentially result in limb amputation.

 

Option. C. Venom suction: Venom suction is never an option in the management of snake bites.

 

Option. D. See the snake brought by the relatives: Looking at the snake brought by relatives is rarely of practical use and is more of a theoretical consideration. It should not be the first step in managing a snake bite with signs of envenomation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In cases of snake bites with signs of envenomation, such as pain, swelling, and bleeding, administering polyvalent ASV should be the first step in management, regardless of the type of snake involved.

questions.text: Most preferred chromatography for HbA1c? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ion-exchange chromatography

 

  • Ion-exchange chromatography is the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis that separates molecules based on their charge.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis,

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrophoresis:

  • Electrophoresis is a technique that separates molecules based on their charge and size.
  • It is not the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis because it may not provide the specificity and accuracy needed for precise quantification of glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Affinity chromatography:

  • Affinity chromatography separates glycated hemoglobin based on its specific affinity for a stationary phase that can selectively bind to HbA1c.

 

Option D. Immuno turbidimetry:

  • Immuno turbidimetry is a technique that measures the concentration of substances in a solution based on the degree of turbidity.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis, it may not be as specific as affinity chromatography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

questions.text: What post-translational modification is essential for the stability of collagen, contributes to oxygen sensing in hemoglobin regulation, and affects immunoglobulin glycosylation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydroxylation

 

Explanation: 

 

Hydroxylation is a crucial post-translational modification that plays important roles in all three proteins:

 

  • Collagen: Requires proline and lysine hydroxylation for proper triple helix formation and stability. This process is vitamin C-dependent.
  • Hemoglobin: HIF (Hypoxia-Inducible Factor) hydroxylation regulates hemoglobin synthesis through oxygen sensing. Prolyl hydroxylases modify HIF-α subunits in an oxygen-dependent manner.
  • Immunoglobulins: Hydroxylation affects N-glycosylation patterns, which are important for immunoglobulin function and clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splicing: This is a post-transcriptional modification occurring at the RNA level, not a post-translational protein modification.

 

Option B. Gene editing: This involves DNA modification and is not a post-translational process.

 

Option C. Subunit aggregation: While this occurs in all three proteins, it's not a chemical modification but rather a physical assembly process.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hydroxylation is a key post-translational modification that affects the structure and function of various proteins through different mechanisms - direct stabilization in collagen, oxygen sensing for hemoglobin regulation, and glycosylation patterns in immunoglobulins.

choices.text: Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition.
In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.
Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source.
Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about postmortem changes? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. In cases of drowning, postmortem hypostasis is seen only in lower limbs.

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts. In drowning, the body floats with face down, buttocks up, legs and arms hanging down in front of the body as shown below:

 

 

Hence, in drowning the postmortem staining occurs over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Greenish discoloration in right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition: Greenish discoloration after death occurs due to sulfmethemoglobin.

 

Earliest external sign of decomposition: greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

 

Earliest internal sign of putrefaction: reddish brown discoloration of aorta followed by greenish discoloration of undersurface of liver.

 

Option C. Adipocere is seen in bodies recovered from water source: Adipocere formation requires presence of moisture, hence found in bodies recovered from water.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm is seen only in specific group of muscles: Cadaveric spasm is the localized sustained contraction of a specific set of muscles which were used profusely just before death. There is no primary relaxation phase and these muscles become stiff and rigid immediately after death. For example, in case of death due to drowning, if the person grabs hold of grass, then immediately after death, he would be having a clenched fist with some grass in it. On the contrary rigor mortis occurs in all the body muscles gradually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts of the body based on the position at the time of death. In drowning cases, it affects the face, neck, chest, and limbs, not just the lower limbs.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

 

Dimercaprol is a traditional chelating agent of choice for acute arsenic poisoning. Though now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Amongst the given choices, dimercaprol is best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipecac: Ipecac is rapidly acting anti-emetic. Earlier it was sometimes used to remove different types of unabsorbed poisons in GIT, but now it is no longer recommended due to limited benefits

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Though it can be used in arsenic, but not a preferred agent. It is preferred chelator for copper.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Not useful as it does not adsorb arsenic and other heavy metals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning

 

  • Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • Chelating Agents
    • Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
    • There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning:
      1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity.
      2. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
      3. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

choices.text: Primary, secondary and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation
Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds
Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tertiary structure is three dimensional

 

Explanation:

 

The tertiary structure of proteins refers to the overall three-dimensional arrangement of a polypeptide chain, shaped by various interactions including hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and van der Waals forces. This structure is crucial for the protein's functional specificity, allowing the precise positioning of amino acid side chains necessary for biological activity. The three-dimensional nature of tertiary structure is essential for the functionality of enzymes and other proteins in biological systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation: Denaturation typically affects secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures, but the primary structure, which is the sequence of amino acids linked by peptide bonds, remains intact. Therefore, this statement is partially correct but not entirely.

 

Option C. Secondary structure is stabilized by disulphide bonds: Disulphide bonds primarily stabilize tertiary and sometimes quaternary structures by forming covalent links between different parts of the protein or between different protein subunits. Secondary structures like alpha-helices and beta-sheets are primarily stabilized by hydrogen bonds.

 

Option D. Secondary and Tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence: While this statement holds truth in that the primary sequence does dictate the secondary and tertiary structures due to the chemical properties of the amino acids involved, it's not the complete answer regarding the "true" statement sought by the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Structure of proteins –

 

  1. Primary structure of protein means the order of amino acids in the polypeptide chain and the location of disulfide bonds, if any.
  2. Secondary structure is the formed by folding of primary structure by hydrogen bonding between various residues. Example alpha helix, beta-pleated sheets, loops, and bends
  3. Tertiary structure denotes the overall 3D arrangement formed by interactions of the various regions, or domains of a single polypeptide chain. The tertiary structure is maintained by noncovalent interactions between amino acid residue such as hydrophobic bonds, electrostatic bonds and van der Waals forces.
  4. Quaternary structure results when the proteins consist of two or more polypeptide chains held together by noncovalent forces like hydrogen bonds, electrostatic bonds, hydrophobic bonds and van der Waals forces.

 

There will be nonspecific alterations in secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures of protein molecules. Primary structure is not altered during denaturation.

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. A preservative was used to preserve his viscera. Which of the following poisoning is seen in it? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aconite

 

The question describes a scenario of sudden death where a preservative was used to preserve the viscera. The key point here is the suspicion of poisoning leading to sudden death. Aconite is a well-known cardiac poison that can cause sudden death by affecting the heart's function. Cardiac poisons such as aconite disrupt normal cardiac activity, leading to fatal arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol poisoning can be fatal, it typically does not cause sudden death in the manner described. The symptoms and progression of alcohol poisoning differ significantly from those of cardiac poisons.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning usually presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity. It is less likely to cause sudden cardiac death compared to aconite.

 

Option D. Thymol: Thymol is an antiseptic and fungicide, not typically associated with poisoning that leads to sudden death. Its toxic effects do not align with the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite is a potent cardiac poison known for causing sudden death due to its severe impact on cardiac function

 

Cardiac poisons: Mnemonic - DHONAQ

 

Digitalis, Hydrogen cyanide, Oleander, Nicotine, Aconite, and Quinine.

questions.text: A skin rash gets exaggerated on sun exposure is repaired by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair

 

 

Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from the sun causes damage to DNA by inducing the formation of thymidine dimers, which are covalent linkages between adjacent thymine bases on a DNA strand. These dimers distort the DNA structure, interfering with replication and transcription.

 

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the primary mechanism used by cells to repair this type of damage. The NER pathway identifies the bulky lesions caused by thymidine dimers, excises the damaged section of DNA, and fills in the gap with the correct nucleotides using a DNA polymerase.

 

A defect in this repair mechanism can lead to xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, leading to severe sunburns, rashes, and a high risk of skin cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair: This mechanism repairs small, non-bulky DNA lesions such as single-base alterations, including deamination and oxidative damage. It does not correct UV-induced thymidine dimers.

 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA break repair: This repair mechanism is involved in fixing double-strand breaks, which occur due to radiation, replication errors, or certain chemicals. It does not address thymidine dimers.

 

Option C. Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as incorrect base pairing (e.g., A-C instead of A-T). It is not involved in repairing damage from UV light exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleotide excision repair is the primary DNA repair mechanism that corrects damage caused by UV light, such as thymidine dimers.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy will have ____ permanent and ____ temporary teeth?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Mixed dentition is a period when both temporary (primary) and permanent teeth are present in the oral cavity. This phase typically occurs between the ages of 6 to 11 years.

 

Key points to remember about mixed dentition:

 

1. Age Range: The mixed dentition period spans from 6 to 11 years.

 

2. Total Number of Teeth: During mixed dentition, the total number of teeth (temporary plus permanent) is consistently 24.

 

3. Calculation of Permanent Teeth: The number of permanent teeth can be calculated using the formula:

 

Permanent Teeth=(Age−5)×4

 

For a 10-year-old child:

 

Permanent Teeth=(10−5)×4=20

 

Hence, the number of permanent teeth is 20.

 

4. Calculation of Temporary Teeth: The number of temporary teeth can be determined by subtracting the number of permanent teeth from the total number of teeth:

 

Temporary Teeth=24−Permanent Teeth

 

Therefore:

 

Temporary Teeth=24−20=4

 

Thus, a 10-year-old boy will have 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the mixed dentition period (6-11 years), a 10-year-old typically has 20 permanent teeth and 4 temporary teeth. Use the formula (Age−5)×4  to determine the number of permanent teeth.
